contentblocks.title: corkboardIntro
contentblocks.content:
The Corkboard is for posting needs, FREE items, events and job opportunities only.

When posting, select the appropriate category so your listing can be found easily. Posts that stray from these guidelines will be removed (no hard feelings). If someone is interested in your post, you'll receive an email.

Posts are deleted after 30 days to keep things neat and tidy.

contentblocks.title: myTrips
contentblocks.content:
My Trips 

Manage your trips.

Use this page to view your trips and check your fundraising progress. You can also share your fundraising page with your family and friends by using the social links below. And don't forget to send them a thank you message when they donate to your trip.

contentblocks.title: TripEmergencyContact
contentblocks.content: This needs to be someone not going on the trip. We will notify them in the event of an emergency and may contact them when the group arrives at the trip destination.

contentblocks.title: TripRandomLottery
contentblocks.content: We will use a random lottery if we have more people sign up than available spots. While we must prepare for this, it is very rare. A deposit is required to be considered for the lottery. If you are not selected, your deposit will be refunded.

contentblocks.title: TripGroupCommonName
contentblocks.content: Do you have friends signing up that you would like to experience this trip with? If yes, everyone in your group should enter a common participant name through which you have all agreed to be connected. This is how we will know to treat you as a group. For example, if Jim Smith, Sarah Johnson and Kerry Moore all want to travel together, they can all enter "Jim Smith" in this section and Jim will be the common link for the group. Note: If you are the one common name, you will still need to enter your name in this section.

contentblocks.title: TripRoommate
contentblocks.content: Everybody on the trip gets a roommate. Married co-ed couples may room together, otherwise you and your significant other will be split up for the trip (no shacking up on Crossroads time).

contentblocks.title: TripPassport
contentblocks.content: Your passport must not be expired within 6 months of the return date of the trip to be valid and have at least 2 blank pages.

contentblocks.title: TripNoPassportIndia
contentblocks.content: You must have a valid passport for an international GO Trip. If you do not have a passport, email goindia@crossroads.net.

contentblocks.title: TripPassportName
contentblocks.content: We'll use this to buy your plane ticket. It must be entered exactly as it appears on your passport. This is frequently an issue for women who have their maiden name on their passport.

contentblocks.title: gpexport_download_desc
contentblocks.content:
Downloading the file will:

  1. Create a tab delimited text file to be saved for import into the accounting system
  2. The file name will be the DepositName_YYMMDD.txt
  3. Mark the selected deposits as exported
  4. Clear your selected deposits
  5. Close this window

NOTE: Please make sure you reviewed and printed the "Selected Deposit - Export Preview" report before clicking to download the report.

contentblocks.title: thedaily_desc
contentblocks.content:
The Daily is going away, but here are some great alternatives:

  • Engage with the Today experience in the Anywhere app (available on the App Store or Google Play).
  • Use the guides in the app (like Five Marks of a Man, Worry, or Group SHOTS!) to kick-start spiritual growth.
  • Looking for a daily bible reading plan? Read Scripture and Through the Word are two other great apps for that.
  • Get the basics of daily Bible reading and start the Crossroads 100 Day Plan.

contentblocks.title: trips_abuse
contentblocks.content: The issue of human trafficking can be overwhelming in a stimulating environment such as India. Answering this question honestly will not disqualify you from this trip but will allow us to better serve you during the pre-trip process.

contentblocks.title: kc_app_disclaimer
contentblocks.content:
OK, here's some formal stuff. We don't really talk like this, but we couldn't figure out how to say all this in kid-friendly language. So put your glasses on, read it and agree to it, please.

The information contained in this application is true. I authorize any reference or church listed here to give you any information (including opinions) that they may have regarding my character and fitness for working with kids. By agreeing to this form, I also consent to a complete criminal background check now and in the future. I understand my involvement with Crossroads Kids' Club is influenced by the information provided by all these sources. I release from liability for damages any person or organizations identified by me in this application, and waive my right to inspect any written material from contact with them or from the criminal background check. I have carefully read the forgoing release and know the contents thereof and I agree to this release as my own free act. This is a legally binding agreement which I have read and understand.

contentblocks.title: TripSupportPersonEmail
contentblocks.content: GO trips can be life changing, mountain-top experiences. It helps to have someone back at home to listen to your story and encourage you when you return. Your support person could be your best friend, your drinking buddy, your mom or your co-worker. We will email them (just once or twice) with some suggestions on how to support you when you get home. We don't want them caught off guard, so please let them know you listed them as a support person! Note: It should NOT be someone who is going on the trip with you.

contentblocks.title: TripGoGroupLeader
contentblocks.content: GO Group Leaders are an essential piece of the leadership team for a GO Trip. Before we leave, their main responsibilities are to communicate between the Trip Leaders and their group members, and to facilitate small group discussion within their group. On the ground, there is the added responsibility to help keep their group safe and accounted for. Once everyone is back home, the GO Group Leader will get the group back together a few more times to both celebrate and reflect on the amazing trip you all took.

contentblocks.title: superbowl_anywhere
contentblocks.content:
We took the weekend when NOBODY went to church, and turned it into our highest-attended weekend of the year (seriously, we don’t know how). It’s an irreverent, schticky, preaching competition that turns church into a spectator sport.

Expect tailgating,
live team competition,
smack-talk,
commercials and
music that’s off the decibel scale.

We’re looking for people to team up for a chance to compete on stage. Fill out the application and tell us why you and your crew should have a chance to taste the glory of winning the Super Bowl*! If you’re chosen, we’ll be in touch with more details.

*Not the real Super Bowl.

Sign up now

We’re expecting 50,000 friends on Super Bowl weekend. Want to help with the biggest party in town?

Sign up to serve

contentblocks.title: groupFinderWelcome
contentblocks.content:
Ready for BRAVE?

Hi there. We’ve put together this awesome, new tool to help you have the best possible BRAVE group experience.

To get started, please log in to your crossroads.net account.

contentblocks.title: groupFinderSummary
contentblocks.content:
BRAVE is a six-week, spiritual journey to explore taking a new step and walk in confidence of who God made us to be.

Through weekend teaching, individual work and meeting with a small group, we’ll be challenged to lean into God and to do new things.

contentblocks.title: groupFinderParticipantExpectations
contentblocks.content:
Let’s find the right group for you

We’ll ask you seven questions that will help us connect you with people who are in a similar spot. (We’ll try to keep the Steelers and Bengals fans separate.)

contentblocks.title: groupFinderHostExpectations
contentblocks.content:
Thanks for stepping up to host a group!

Whether it’s your first or tenth time hosting, we’ll help you connect with the right group.

contentblocks.title: groupFinderHostDashboardHelp

contentblocks.title: groupFinderHostDashboardResources
contentblocks.content:
BRAVE Host Resources

Get your Host Tips here. 

BRAVE WEEK 4

BRAVE EXPERIENCE

Complete your BRAVE Journey by coming to the BRAVE Experience at CityLink Center - it ends May 1. This 60-minute, immersive experience provides space for prayer and listening as you continue to follow your heading and lean into God. It’s a place to be filled, encouraged and strengthened. Make a plan this week to come with your group.

Hours

Monday-Friday: 12-8pm

Saturday: 10am-8pm

Sunday: 2-8pm

*Kids 8 and up are welcome to go through the Experience.

BAPTISMS

The end of BRAVE is marked with open call baptisms. This is a huge, brave step for hundreds of people after the Journey (some are likely in your group). For more information or to register, check out crossroads.net/baptism.

WHAT'S AFTER BRAVE?

Continue meeting with your group! Whether or not you still host, encourage your group to continue meeting and use the content in the Daily for your group. You can access the group questions in the Daily in the Crossroads Anywhere App or in your email. Check out crossroads.net/daily for more information.

+++++

WEEK 2 VIDEO

+++++

WEEK 1 VIDEO

HAVE EXTRA SPACE?

If your group has three or less members—don’t take it personally. It’s not you. It’s them. (Trust us. We think you’re a catch.) Here are some potential options for you if you’re unsure:

  1. If you have 2-3 people, go for it. Your group will work.

  2. If you only have one person, check out other groups available and try to bring your one group mate with you. (Seriously, don’t abandon them, and let us know if you do this so we can remove you as a host.)

  3. If no one has joined yours yet, pick another group that works for you, and let us know at host@crossroads.net so we can remove your group from the host list (so others don’t join once it’s closed.)

EMAILING YOUR PEOPLE

We’ve just identified that the “reply-to” when you email your people from the dashboard is a general Crossroads account and not you specifically as the host. We’re working on getting that fixed, but in the meantime, please provide your contact information to the group so they know how to reach you.

And if you haven’t yet, email your people to get them excited for your group this week. Also, be sure to respond to them if they reach out to you.

 

Have questions on hosting? Email us at host@crossroads.net.

contentblocks.title: goVolunteerConnectorInfo

Here is what you need to know as Group Connector.

Once you sign up, we'll list your name with all projects leaders on the site. This does not mean you're leading a project, just helping bring together people you know so you can serve together. Next, you'll choose the type of project you and your friends will do. Make sure you know the ages of any kids that might serve with you. We have to enforce age restrictions for safety reasons.

contentblocks.title: goLocalWaiver
contentblocks.content:
CROSSROADS COMMUNITY CHURCH VOLUNTARY WAIVER OF ALL CLAIMS AND ASSUMPTION OF RISK FORM

I understand in signing this document I do hereby forever waive any and all claims of any type of nature against Crossroads Community Church and release Crossroads Community Church from any and all claims of any type or nature arising from my voluntary agreement to participate as a volunteer on a service project sponsored by the Crossroads Community Church. I understand I assume full and complete responsibility for any accidents, injuries, illnesses or other conditions which may occur en route, during, or as a consequence of my voluntary participation in service work through Crossroads Community Church.

I further understand under no circumstances am I in anyway an employee, agent, officer or director of Crossroads Community Church for purposes of this service project. No representations of any type or nature have been made to me by Crossroads Community Church, its officers, directors or employees concerning my personal safety, health conditions or any other aspects of this service project. I fully understand my participation in this service project may, result in illness, accident or injury occurring as a result of my participation. I have been afforded every opportunity to conduct my own complete and thorough investigation of the conditions surrounding this project and do willingly participate in this service project of my own free will and choice.

I am specifically aware certain hazards and risks to my person and property may be associated with serving in an outreach capacity. I understand such hazards and risk may include, but not be limited to, death or injury by accident, disease, war, terrorist acts or weather conditions, inadequate medical services and supplies, criminal activity, random acts of violence or negligence. I am fully aware of these risks and voluntarily assume them hereby releasing in full any and all claims of any type or nature against Crossroads Community Church, its officers, directors, agents and employees.

I hereby represent I am aware of no medical conditions of any type or nature which I have which would prevent me from participating in this service project and I have been afforded the opportunity, at my sole expense, to be examined by any physician of my selection for purposes of verifying my physical condition. I further have been advised I have the right to have an attorney of my selection and at my expense review this waiver and release prior to signing of this document and have either done so to my own satisfaction as evidenced by my signature hereon, or by signing this document have waived my right to have this matter reviewed by an attorney of my selection and at my expense.

I expressly waive any defense to the enforcement of any provision of this contractual agreement arising from any claim of lack of consideration and understand this document constitutes a legal, valid and binding waiver of my rights and shall be enforceable against me, my family or my estate for any and all purposes whatsoever. I understand I am not being covered under any policy or policies of insurance issued to Crossroads Community Church or its agents, officers, directors and employees which would provide me any type of coverages for my participation in this trip other than may have been expressly provided to me in writing, and I hereby affirm and attest no oral representations, promises or statements have been made in any respect effecting my participation in this service project or any of the terms or conditions of this waiver and release other than as expressly written herein.

I also understand for all purposes this agreement shall be construed under the laws of the State of Ohio. I hereby further state I have carefully read all of the terms and conditions set forth in this waiver and release of all claims, that I fully and completely understand all information set forth herein and I voluntarily agree to this waiver and release as my own free act understanding fully this is a legally binding document.

contentblocks.title: braveAtHomeIntro1
contentblocks.content:
Welcome to the BRAVE at Home Challenge. This experience will take about 30 minutes to complete.

Note: This experience requires a crossroads.net account. You can sign in or register on the next page.

Get Started

contentblocks.title: braveAtHomeIntro2
contentblocks.content:
We created this experience to give you the space to hear from God—to hear his plan for your home. In the next 30 minutes, we'll help you think about how your home can be a home base for the brave life God has for you.

Continue

contentblocks.title: braveAtHomeIntro3
contentblocks.content:
Setup

This is an audio experience designed for headphones. Make sure you grab yours before moving on.

Each section contains an audio player which will guide you through the experience, as well as a challenge or activity to complete. You can move forward or backward through the audio, pause the audio and even go back to previous sections if you need.

To minimize distractions, set your phone to “do not disturb.”

When you’re ready, hit continue.

Continue

contentblocks.title: braveAtHomeRoom1
contentblocks.content:
Let’s Get Started

Loading audio

Hit the play button to begin.

When you're ready, hit next to continue.

Back
Next
Step: 1/8

contentblocks.title: braveAtHomeRoom2
contentblocks.content:
Bedroom

Loading audio

Hit the play button when you're ready to begin.

Challenge Reminder: Before continuing, write “HELP ME BE BRAVE” in big letters on a card or piece of paper. Put it where your phone or alarm clock wakes you up. Then hit next.

Back
Next
Step: 2/8

contentblocks.title: braveAtHomeRoom3
contentblocks.content:
Bathroom

Loading audio

Hit the play button when you're ready to begin.

“For God gave us a spirit not of fear but of power and love and self-control.” – 2 Tim 1:7

“Have I not commanded you? Be strong and courageous. Do not be frightened, and do not be dismayed, for the Lord your God is with you wherever you go.” – Joshua 1:9

“Be strong, and let your heart take courage, all you who wait for the Lord!” – Psalm 31:24

Challenge Reminder: Write down the scripture that stands out to you the most and put it where you’ll see it every day.

Back
Next
Step: 3/8

contentblocks.title: braveAtHomeRoom4
contentblocks.content:
Living Room

Loading audio

Hit the play button when you're ready to begin.

Challenge Reminder: Text or email a friend to thank them for the role they play in your life. Invite them into your BRAVE journey. Then come back to this page and hit next.

Back
Next
Step: 4/8

contentblocks.title: braveAtHomeRoom5
contentblocks.content:
Threshold

Loading audio

Hit the play button when you're ready to begin.

Challenge Reminder: Draw (or scratch) that outward facing arrow on the doorframe of your front door. Make your mark. Commit to follow Jesus in whatever brave direction he leads you.

Back
Next
Step: 5/8

contentblocks.title: braveAtHomeShare
contentblocks.content:
Share

Do you know someone in your life who could use a little bravery? Share this experience with them and talk about it afterwards.

Whether they live two doors down or halfway across the world, don’t let them miss out on this experience.

Or copy this into a text or email:

I just finished the BRAVE at Home Challenge. You should totally check it out. http://crds.ch/bravehometxt

When you’re done, you can close this window. Thanks for taking the BRAVE at Home Challenge!

Step: 8/8

contentblocks.title: braveAtHomeReflect
contentblocks.content:
Reflect

Reflecting makes our experiences stick. Take two minutes and think about what you just experienced. What surprised you? What was meaningful? What did you hear from God?

In the box below, finish this sentence: “This experience helped me...”

Back
Next
Step: 6/8

Prayer

Has God helped you see your home differently as a result of this experience? Do you see how your home can be the home base for the brave life God has for you?

Write a prayer in the box below about how you hope God uses your home over the next few weeks and months. Here's an example to get you started:

"God, give me the power to be brave. Fill this home with Your Spirit, so it can be a place of rest, rhythm and exciting opportunities. Bring people into my life and into my home who can help me be brave and pursue the good things You have for me."

Amen! In a few weeks, we’ll send this prayer back to you. We hope you’ll be amazed with all of the ways God shows up between now and then.

Hit next to finish.

Back
Next
Step: 7/8

contentblocks.title: groupToolRemoveParticipantSubheaderText
contentblocks.content:
This is where you can remove a participant from your group - are you sure you want to do this? This should only occur when:

  1. the participant has requested to be removed, or
  2. there’s a legitimate reason why you’re removing them from the group.

If you’re removing someone from the group, the individual should be aware this is taking place prior to them being removed via the group tool. (Meaning, there should have been some other communication (preferably in person) so this doesn’t come as a surprise.)

contentblocks.title: streamingLandingIntro
contentblocks.content:
Ready to leave the daily grind? So are we.

Welcome to Crossroads Anywhere

contentblocks.title: streamingLandingCurrentSeries
contentblocks.content:
TOGETHERRUNS: August 6th - August 28th

How to Make & Keep Better Friends. Lone wolves, rugged individualists, and detached hermits all have one thing in common: they die. God created us to thrive TOGETHER. But it's not always easy. Join us as we talk about how to make TOGETHER work for all of us.

Topics covered:
friends, #letsbetogether, groups

Watch Trailer

contentblocks.title: streamingLandingCommunity
contentblocks.content:
We Are Where You Are

Crossroads Anywhere is more than "church TV." It's friends and neighbors meeting across the country in living rooms to hear a relevant, biblical message we can apply to our everyday lives.

Invite your friends:

contentblocks.title: streamingLandingHostIntro
contentblocks.content:
Create a Community Where You Are

We believe growth happens in community. It's kinda our thing.

contentblocks.title: streamingLandingHostTips
contentblocks.content:
Learn to Host

You want to start a community - we want to help. Start by hosting a weekend service. Open up your home, make some coffee, and invite people you know. If you want to take hosting to the next level and build community, there is a group just for you! When you join, you'll get weekly updates, tips to prepare for service, and connection to a community of hosts all over the country.

Learn about Hosting

contentblocks.title: streamingLandingHostBecome
contentblocks.content:
Be a Leader

Got hosting down? Time to lead. Leaders are interested in going beyond the weekend–they want to actively follow God and help others do the same. Lead a group that watches service together, serves together, and does life together. As a leader, you can list your group online and get access to all kinds of resources to make your group awesome. (Oh, and we can connect you with a coach too - if you want.)

Apply to Lead a Group

contentblocks.title: streamingLandingHostKids
contentblocks.content:
Kids are welcome

Not quite sure what to do with your kids during service? Want them to have a meaningful experience with God? We've got you covered. With Kids’ Club Anywhere, you can download lessons, presentations, and get tips on creating an great environment to help your kids connect with God.

Check it out here

contentblocks.title: streamingLandingCurrentSeriesImage
streamingLandingPastWeekend1
contentblocks.content:
You can’t say that in church

Brian Tome talks about what people think should and shouldn’t be allowed to say in church.

contentblocks.title: streamingLandingPastWeekend2
contentblocks.content:
The Unparalleled Power of Community & Data and Discovering Why God Made You

Matt Welty talks about how important community is to your personal and spiritual growth. Dave Kinnaman talks about the importance of work and how it is God's design for our lives.

contentblocks.title: streamingLandingPastWeekend3
contentblocks.content:
We stand Undivided

Chuck Mingo talks about community and how to respond to the terrible race-related violence and rising tensions in our country.

contentblocks.title: streamingLandingPastWeekend4
contentblocks.content:
Why my daughter will fail statistics. & How a suitcase and $800 changed my life.

Latasha Patrick talks about how being a single mother left her determined for her and her daughter to not fall to statics. Paco Pancham talks about how having faith and taking a risk changed his family's life with $800 and a suitcase.

contentblocks.title: groupToolCreateGroupAboutExample
contentblocks.content:
Example of a group name and description:

Name:  Couples Huddle
Description: For couples who want to be discipled and become disciple-makers themselves. We'll center this group around "Huddle" content that trains us to reproduce the life of Jesus in ourselves and others. We'll meet weekly in my home in Florence.

contentblocks.title: groupToolCreateGroupVisibility
contentblocks.content: Set your group to public or private.

contentblocks.title: groupToolCreateGroupVisibilityHelp
contentblocks.content:
Choose whether your group will be viewable to everyone or only the people in your group.

You can control your group’s size. Once your group hits the number of folks you want in it, simply go to the group details and change the group to “private” instead of “public.” If a spot opens up, you can edit it to be “public” so your group becomes searchable again. As a leader, you have the ability to "deny" people if for some reason you get an influx of invites before your group is set to private. Just deny them kindly, explain that your group is full, and set your group to private so others don’t have the ability to join.

(Note: you’ll be able to invite people directly into your group regardless of if you make your group public or private.)

contentblocks.title: groupToolCreateGroupCategory
contentblocks.content: How will your group be categorized?

contentblocks.title: groupToolCreateGroupCategoryHelp
contentblocks.content:
Your group can do a lot together, but the best groups have a primary function. Select the category that best describes your group. (You can select multiple if needed.) Then use one or two words to describe your Group Category (e.g. Norwood, boxing, Book of James).

Note:  25 characters is the maximum length for the detail, so keep it brief. Also, don't enter these characters ( &,',#) since it will not create the group correctly (we are working on a fix for this.)

contentblocks.title: groupToolNeighborhoodDescription
contentblocks.content: Your group is primarily focused on building community with the people who live closest together in your town, zip code or on your street.

contentblocks.title: groupToolSpiritualGrowthDescription
contentblocks.content: Grow together through Huddle, reading a book or studying the Bible and applying what you learn to your everyday life.

contentblocks.title: groupToolInterestDetail
contentblocks.content: For people who share a common activity. From cooking to karate, motorcycles to frisbee golf, veterans or entrepreneurs, whatever your interest, we bet there’s a group looking for it.

contentblocks.title: groupToolHealingDescription
contentblocks.content: For people looking for healing and recovery in an area of life like grief, infertility, addiction, divorce, crisis, etc.

Start a Group

If you already have some friends who want to join your group, hang tight—you’ll have a chance to invite them later.

streamingLandingIntroOff
contentblocks.content:
Ready to leave the daily grind? So are we.

Hi. Welcome to Crossroads Anywhere!

No matter what you believe, we built this for you - and the thousands like you - who want to live by a different set of rules.

contentblocks.title: streamingLandingIntroUpcoming
contentblocks.content:
Hi. Welcome to Crossroads Anywhere!

We're setting up for our next live stream. Grab a coffee, gather your friends and hold tight.

 

This isn't your average "church TV." We're groups of people meeting in person every week to explore who God is in a language we can understand. Whether you're exploring whether or not God exists or a you're committed Christ-follower, we're glad you're here.

On this page, you can attend a Crossroads service, find friends nearby and learn more about hosting in your own home.

contentblocks.title: campMedicationPolicy
contentblocks.content:
Medication Policy

I understand that it is my responsibility to give the medication directly to a camp volunteer with full instructions and all medications in original prescription bottles.  Adult volunteer(s) have our permission to MONITOR our student’s taking of any medications.  Monitor shall mean that the volunteer(s) shall provide an opportunity for the student to take the medication as close to the scheduled time as possible, provide the medication to the student, and observe the student taking the medication, to the best of their ability.  The volunteer nor Crossroads may be held liable for the failure of the student to take the medication as prescribed.

contentblocks.content: DDK (Digital Design Kit)

contentblocks.title: dashboardIntroCopy
contentblocks.content:
Welcome to the official, online style-guide for crossroads.net digital properties. This website represents the “single source of truth” when working on any digital materials or applications for the Crossroads brand.

From prototyping to QA, the DDK is a comprehensive library of battle-tested UX patterns and technical solutions built atop a rock solid foundation that supports a wide array of browsers and platforms. Custom-designed for the Crossroads brand – this is a living, breathing digital reference manual designed to get teams moving faster through the use of a cohesive stylistic language. This means minimal QA effort and a dramatic reduction to time spent in acceptance review.

contentblocks.content:
ARCHDIOCESE OF CINCINNATIADULT PERMISSION, RELEASE AND MEDICAL POWER OF ATTORNEY (rev. 10-2014)

1. I, the undersigned will participate in the activity described on the Activity Information form and release from all liability and indemnify the Archbishop of Cincinnati (“the Archbishop”), both individually and as trustee for the Archdiocese of Cincinnati and all parishes and schools within the Archdiocese (the “Archdiocese”), agents, representatives, volunteers, and employees of the Archdiocese, from any and all liability, claims, judgments, cost and expenses, including attorneys’ fees, arising out of any injury or illness incurred by me while participating in or traveling to or from the activity and further agree not to bring or prosecute or allow to be brought or prosecuted (including but not limited to prosecution through subrogation) in my name,  any claims, lawsuits or actions against the Archbishop, and the officers, agents, representatives, volunteers and employees of the Archdiocese,.
2. I further understand that my participation is purely voluntary and is a privilege and not a right. I elect to participate in spite of the risks.
3. I agree to cooperate with the Archbishop or his agents in charge of the activity.
4. I appoint the Archbishop or his agents who are acting as leaders of the activity as my attorney in fact to act for me in my name and my behalf, in any way that I would act if I were personally present, with respect to the following matters if any injury, illness or medical emergency occurs during the activity or related travel:
(i) To give any and all consents and authorizations to any physicians, dentist, hospital or other persons or institutions pertaining to any emergency medications, medical or dental treatments, diagnostic or surgical procedures or any other emergency actions as our attorney shall deem necessary or appropriate for my best interest.

5. This power of attorney shall lapse automatically upon completion of the activity and related travel.
6. I agree that the Archbishop or his agents may use my child’s portrait or photograph for promotional purposes, website and office functions and use social media and technology to communicate to my child regarding ministry related activities. (Facebook, texting, etc.)
7. This acknowledgement and release is intended to be as broad and inclusive as permitted by the law of the State of Ohio, and if any portion hereof is declared invalid, it is agreed that the balance shall, notwithstanding, continue in full legal force and effect.  This acknowledgement and release shall be construed in accordance with the laws of the State of Ohio, except for the choice of law provisions thereof.
I have carefully read and understand and accept the terms and conditions stated herein and acknowledge that this Permission, Release and Medical Power of Attorney shall be effective and binding upon me and my own personal representative or estate, assigns, heirs, and next of kin and that I have signed this agreement of my own free will.

contentblocks.title: gettingStarted
contentblocks.content:
Getting started with Crossroads Connect

Connect with others who have an interest in Crossroads by adding yourself to the map. Within a few steps, you can safely exchange email addresses.

While interacting with others, please be smart. You know what the Internet is like. The same rules apply here.

contentblocks.title: whatsAHost
contentblocks.content:
What's a host?

Hosts are normal (and awesome) Crossroads attendees that bring people together to watch a weekend service. They brew up some coffee, open their living rooms, and fire up the Crossroads live stream. Hosts are the hubs of Crossroads communities all over the country. If you do sign up to host, those who you accept into your gathering will be able to view your full address so that they know where to show up. But don't worry - if they are not officially in your gathering, they won't see your exact location - just your city, state, and zip like everyone else on the map.

contentblocks.title: promptToPutSelfOnMap
contentblocks.content:
Hey, you!

Let others in your community know you're here. Put yourself on the map.

contentblocks.title: promptToHostGathering
contentblocks.content:
Want to host a gathering?

Pick a time and a location to watch service. Bonus points you're willing to open your home.

Invite your friends, family, coworker, other people on the map. Seriously, bring anyone. Everyone deserves to hear about God in a language they can understand.

Turn on the TV, brew some coffee, and welcome people to your living room. Life is better in community, so get ready to meet you new best friends.

contentblocks.title: finderGettingStarted
contentblocks.content:
Let’s get started.

Connect is a way to meet Crossroads people across the country and find community. Here’s how it works:

Put yourself on the map - You’ll login or create a crossroads.net account and update your profile information.

Say hi - If you see someone near you, click “Say hi.” The person will get an email letting them know you’d like to connect.

Check your email - That’s how you’ll know when someone says hi to you. Respond as soon as possible to make a new friend. 

While interacting with others, please be smart. You know what the Internet is like. The same rules apply here.

contentblocks.title: imInLeaveyourmark
contentblocks.content:
Since November 2015, the Crossroads team has been charging after a three-year financial campaign called I’M IN. It’s a bold, risky mission to take enemy ground for the Kingdom. To broadcast a clear voice of truth through a barrage of lies. To bring spiritual and physical freedom to the oppressed. To run after our friends and neighbors, introducing them to a God that loves and pursues them. No matter where He calls us, we’re in.

Check Your Status

Featured Projects

In 2017, we used I'M IN Campaign dollars to expand Crossroads West Side. The seats were so packed that some had to sit in overflow and watch a video feed, and there was never enough parking. So $5.3 million went into doubling the size of the auditorium, expanding the atrium and paving a brand new parking lot. The renovations were complete for Easter weekend and the space is incredible. Most importantly, we now have room to invite more of our friends and neighbors in to meet a God who loves them.

We want to use buildings to meet people where they are in their own communities and to be a resource and a gathering place, so construction of our East Side location is underway. Slated to open in January, 2018, this 125,000 sq ft site is going up right next door to the Eastgate Jungle Jim’s. It will house a 2,100 seat auditorium, chapel, atrium, and spaces for kids and students. The excitement is building, much more to come.

In 2016, we used I’M IN Campaign dollars to purchase 430 acres of land, and have since hosted camps for thousands of men and women, including the first Couples Camp. 700 couples came out for a weekend in April to connect with God, friends, and each other. There’s something special that happens when we get outside of our normal routines and away from distractions. God saved marriages that weekend. Interested in Couples Camp? The second round is coming this September.

Hundreds of women are finding wholeness and renewed purpose. This wouldn’t happen if we didn’t answer the call to fight for them. We've partnered with the local Indian church to provide education, skills training, jobs, housing, and family to rescued survivors of trafficking.

Over 30 Indian and Nepali students are tutored by Crossroads volunteers every week through our online program. Those students in Kolkata and Mumbai are not only getting jobs, but are being sought out by potential employers because of their high level of skill.

Stories from the field

Share Your Story

Questions?

If you have any questions, email giving@crossroads.net.

contentblocks.title: groupLeaderAppInfo
contentblocks.content:
Way to step up and lead a group

You’re about to begin the approval process toward becoming a group leader. This process will help us learn more about you.

To become a leader, you must fill out the following application which includes the following steps:

  1. Watch a group vision/training video
  2. Agree to the "I Promise" agreement
  3. Confirm your profile information and answer a couple of questions about your background
  4. Answer a couple of questions about your spiritual growth

We’ll review your application and then send you an email giving you the thumbs up to continue or ask you a few more questions.

contentblocks.title: groupLeaderPromise_01
contentblocks.content:
To Be Hospitable

I commit to being friendly, warm and welcoming by giving access to my home and family.

John 13:35

contentblocks.title: groupLeaderPromiseHeader
contentblocks.content:
At Crossroads, we have a document known as “I Promise” that calls out the principles we strive to live by to honor God and each other. Leaders and staff regularly sign it as a way to commit to do these things.

We want you to know and consider what is expected when you make this commitment. Nobody’s perfect, we just want leaders to commit to doing their best to honor God and others when leading groups. Read the principles below, consider what they mean.

Check each one if you agree to live by these promises.

contentblocks.title: groupLeaderConfirmation

contentblocks.content: Print

contentblocks.title: groupLeaderPromise_02
contentblocks.content:
To Make Room For People To Be Who They Are And Meet Them There

I realize some people may be at different places on their spiritual journey. I will ask for God to lead me as I lead each person.

1 Corinthians 3:7

contentblocks.title: groupLeaderPromise_03
contentblocks.content:
To Be a Spiritual Leader

I recognize I’m not just a “host” for this group. I will take the lead in being vulnerable, sharing my story, praying, and discipling our group to look more like Jesus. I will seek God’s direction and regularly discern where people are with God and help them move to the next place spiritually.

Mark 10:42-45

contentblocks.title: groupLeaderPromise_04
contentblocks.content:
To Practice Spiritual Disciplines

So that Christ becomes strengthened in me. This includes but is not limited to Bible reading, prayer, tithing, fasting, solitude, etc.

1 Corinthians 9:25

contentblocks.title: groupLeaderPromise_05
contentblocks.content:
To Use The Bible As My Ultimate Standard Of Truth

It is God's word and is more accurate than my culture, opinions, feelings, passions and perspectives.

2 Timothy 3:16-17

contentblocks.title: groupLeaderPromise_06
contentblocks.content:
To Live A Godly Life In Parallel With The Bible's Teachings

This includes, but is not limited to: drug and alcohol abuse, same sex and/or extra-marital sex, violent actions, greed, slander, control, etc.

1 Peter 1:14-16

contentblocks.title: groupLeaderPromise_07
contentblocks.content:
To Go Directly To The Person I Have A Concern With Prior To Enlisting Support From Other People

If after the initial difficult conversation, I still don't feel right, I will ask someone who might feel the same way if they will go with me to resume the difficult conversation. If after that interaction I haven't been satisfied then I will find a person in a position of leadership and seek their guidance.

Matthew 18:15-17

contentblocks.title: groupLeaderPromise_08
contentblocks.content:
To Trust Those In Authority Over Me

I will remember that when a decision is made I may not have all of the information nor the responsibility of those in leadership. I will not be a burden to authorities and leaders in the church.

Hebrews 13:17

contentblocks.title: groupLeaderPromise_09
contentblocks.content:
To Follow-Through On My Commitments And Fully Engage With Crossroads Group Leader Stuff

I will attend required trainings, respond to emails about my group, train others to lead, etc. I realize that when I don’t do what I said I would do, I dishonor God and those in my community.

Matthew 5:37

contentblocks.title: groupLeaderPromise_10
contentblocks.content:
To Pray For The Members Of My Group

I realize that one of the most important ways I can support the people in my group is to pray for them.

Philippians 4:6

contentblocks.title: userHomePage
contentblocks.content:
Hi. 

Whatever your thoughts on church, whatever
your beliefs about God, you are welcome here.

Get to know us.
.

Our Current Series

March 25 – April 9
We humans are tragically limited: modern science says we are blind to 99% of color and confined to a measly 4 out of 26 known dimensions. The harsh reality is we are missing out on most of what's real—stuck with a limited view. But there are people—both ancient and modern—who have gone beyond the boundaries. BEYOND is a 3 week teaching series based on their stories that will take you past your limits and teach you how to tap into the power of God. 

Crossroads is one church happening in multiple locations

Find one near you »

Relationships are critical for growth.

We’re open.

If you live near our campus in Oakley, Florence, Mason, Uptown or Oxford, come hang out in our building during the week. Free Wi-Fi and coffee.

Open Hours

contentblocks.title: DesignersGuidelinesIntro
contentblocks.content:
Introduction

If you’ve made it here, you are no doubt a designer. And you’re probably looking to create something for Crossroads. To help you get started, we’ve compiled everything you need to create designs that are consistent with the Crossroads look and feel.

Things to keep in mind before/while you create:

  • Have you considered your audience?
  • What is the goal of the web page/app?
  • Can you simplify the messaging or the design in an effort to communicate more clearly?

When starting new projects, products, etc., it’s a good idea to come back and check for updates to the style guide. This is a living guide that will change, evolve, and grow.

contentblocks.title: DesignersGuidelinesColor
contentblocks.content:
Color Usage

The color palette of Crossroads was inspired by the original building. Blues, gray, black, and white are all used to convey the bold, masculine tone. The yellow and rust colors are used minimally.

White Space

White space is awesome. It helps give a pause—allowing someone to take in appropriate amounts of visual information. Overwhelming the visitor with too much visual information hinders their ability to connect with our messaging.

Floods of Color

Floods of color are great too. They create visual interest and reinforce our brand. 95% of the time, color floods should be Crossroads Blue - #3B6E8F. 5% of the time, one of our grays can be used. If you find that your design would be made that much better with a different color, you’re probably wrong, but give it a try and share it with us anyway.

Check out our color palette

Check out some examples of our color palette in action.

  • Connect
  • Live Streaming

contentblocks.title: DesignersGuidelinesCopy
contentblocks.content:
Copy/Voice

All content should be approved by Adam George before being published to the web.

Voice:

Crossroads uses informal, conversational language that is seeker-friendly and non-churchy. Our voice is inclusive (no inside jokes, please) and our readability is simple and accessible. The voice of Crossroads should strive to be honest, easy and friendly.

What’s a seeker?

Someone who’s asking questions, from simple curiosity to deep soul-searching. A season of looking for truth, healing, and something to stand on. Seeking God for the first time, God again, or just God in this new community of Crossroads.

Audience:

We assume that seekers are not familiar with “churchy” language, or that they have negative baggage associated with it. For example, we do not use phrases like “born-again Christian” or “are you saved?” We don’t assume seekers would label themselves as such. Therefore, we don’t use the word “seekers” when speaking to this audience. Instead, we use phrases like “those who want to know more about God.”

When writing a piece for a particular ministry area, it’s critical to consider your audience. For example, Student Ministry would not write a letter addressed to students in the same way they would write a letter to parents.

A Note About Funny:

Crossroads has a great sense of humor. We love to be funny, but there is no rule that everything that’s written has to be funny. Sometimes funny can be distracting, and not everyone’s sense of humor translates well in print. When writing, just ask yourself, “do I feel funny right now?” If the answer is no, it’s OK to write something not funny. It isn’t worth the risk of being misunderstood or having a bad joke flop.

Things we say:Things we don’t say:
  • community
  • spiritual journey
  • people who attend Crossroads
  • social event / celebration
  • message / talk
  • Christ-followers
  • fellowship / congregation
  • walk with the Lord
  • guests / attendees / members
  • pot luck / fish fry
  • sermon
  • Christians / family of believers

Holy Capitalization!

  • When the word God appears, do not capitalize he in the same sentence.
  • Capitalize the first He when referring to God or Jesus if God or Jesus does not precede he.
  • Do not capitalize He after the first he has been capitalized in a sentence.
  • Bible is capitalized, biblical is not.

Clear as mud? Check out this example:

God loves us and he cares for us. The people love Him. We receive from Him because he loves us. All of these statements are biblical because they appear in the Bible.

Avoid these:

Certain writing tendencies can create disconnects for the reader. Here are some examples of common pitfalls to avoid:

“Here at Crossroads...”
Avoid communication that creates an “us and them” feeling, like “at Crossroads, we like to...”
“Let’s dive deeper beyond the arm’s length of the weekend and unpack the lies we’ve come to believe about ourselves as we do life together.”
Avoid too much Crossroads jargon. Not everyone’s familiar with these phrases, and many of them have become cliché.
“These things are great stuff...”
Avoid non-descript words like things and stuff.
“Have you ever wondered what everyone is wondering? Have questions? Have you ever wondered who to contact about questions about what everyone is wondering?”
Avoid using too many questions, especially at the beginning.
“We have nothing to fear but fear itself.”
Avoid starting with a quote (or a Bible verse, for that matter).
“love on”
It sounds weird, especially with a reference to kids.
“receive” or “receiving”
These aren’t all bad, but really consider another word first. These tend to be overused.

Need some Inspiration?

Check out our manifesto

contentblocks.title: DesignersGuidelinesLogos
contentblocks.content:
Logos

Crossroads Logo

The Crossroads word mark is good old Helvetica Neue Black (tracking -80). Please do not go and create your own version. We know you are very talented. But seriously, just use what we’ve created.

More often than not, the logo should be Crossroads blue, black, white or grey.

Download Crossroads word mark (SVG)

Screwhead Logo

This simple icon is a flexible design element that can be used as part of the Crossroads identity. While created as a simplistic representation of a crossroads, it is not intended to be used as a traditional brandmark. Instead, it is a support piece to be used sparingly throughout a design.

Download screwhead logo (SVG)

Ministries and Sub-Brands

But wait! Crossroads has a ministry called ReachOut. And they have a logo. And then within ReachOut, there are sub-ministries: GO Bolivia, GO India, GO Nicaragua, GO South Africa, GO New Orleans. AND they all have logos.... With no style guide!

We know. Some of our Ministries such as GO Trips, Camps and Kids’ Club have their own branding. It can be confusing. Sorry about that. The simple answer is: if you are working with a specific ministry, ask them for the branding materials that are unique to them.

Have questions?

Contact our communications department

contentblocks.title: DesignersGuidelinesPhotos
contentblocks.content:
Photography

Style

Simple, beautiful, and authentic. How do you like that?

In a perfect world, our photography focuses on a subject (person or object) and has a shallow depth of field. This basically means that anything that isn't the subject of the photo will be a little out of focus.

Effects & Photo Treatments

Sometimes photography is perfect and there is nothing to adjust. And in that case, just leave it be.

Some photos however, need help. We use effects and photo treatments to enhance an image, communicate the Crossroads brand (or the Ministry), and to better connect with content. As with all things, please use responsibly.

  • Duotones (usually with Crossroads blue or gray)
  • Blown out the contrast
  • Industrial textures from our buildings
  • Desaturation

Getting Photography

Almost all of our photography is shot by talented, professional volunteers. We have an extensive library of images that will more than likely meet your needs. The unfortunate thing is we have over 100,000. And we wouldn’t be serving you by making you go through all of them to find 1 particular image—especially if we know how to find it.

If you have particular photography needs, please contact design@crossroads.net.

contentblocks.title: DesignersGuidelinesType
contentblocks.content:
Typography

Crossroads typography is modern and simple. This allows the content to speak for itself by getting out of the way.

Think of a designer’s portfolio website. When you see the titles and description copy it’s more than likely something simple—allowing the work to stand out. That’s what we want to do at Crossroads.

Great care has gone into the development of our typesetting section. When designing something, always start there.

Also, use smart quotes. Don’t know what a smart quote is...we don’t know what to tell you. Actually, we do - check this out: https://www.typewolf.com/cheatsheet

Frequently Asked Questions

What if I’m designing a website for a campaign?
First, thank you for your help. Second, stick with the font families we’ve called out. If the Creative Lead feels like the project warrants new typefaces, we’ll cross that bridge when we get there.
What about series brand graphics? They are always using other typefaces.
That’s true. Good eye! The typographic choices in those cases are made to best communicate the feeling of the series.
I’ve noticed that Woman Camp, Kids’ Club, and Awaited don’t use the “approved” typefaces. What gives?
Yes that is indeed true. Bonus points if you know the fonts they use off the top of your head. Each one has their own brand guidelines. If you are working with a particular ministry or creative lead, please contact them for assets.

contentblocks.title: DesignersGetStartedMobile
contentblocks.content:
Mobile First

Worldwide, internet usage is dominated by mobile. Therefore, designing digital products shouldn’t simply consider mobile layouts but rather begin with them. This is Mobile First design. Because of the reduced screen sizes, designing for mobile is inherently beneficial for communicating content hierarchy, navigation systems and simplicity of layout. It forces us to put our best foot forward. The constraints force us into designing and building lean products that are easy to use.

As the device’s viewport grows, the functions and features can increase to utilize the additional screen space, a practice known as progressive enhancement. This workflow also helps us improve speed since we’re only loading what we need at the start. While this strategy makes sense in theory, it comes with plenty of challenge. The screen area can feel rather limiting. So can the libraries of pre-built components or functions. There’s also a tendency to sluff off the larger, desktop design. Fight these pitfalls and accept the challenge. Afterall, solving around constraints is what makes a good designer, a great designer. Love the burn.

contentblocks.title: DesignersGetStartedPrototyping
contentblocks.content:
Prototyping

Whatever you find in the UI Components will, in some way or form, be available for use in Sketch. Instead of spinning your wheels replicating button styles, all these symbols and groups are compiled together in a beautifully organized library. Here’s what you’ll need to do get going with it:

Installing the Library

Step 1: Get Sketch

Sketch is an application created for designing digital products. It’s a snap to learn. Go get Sketch.

Step 2: Install Craft

After using Sketch for a little while, you’ll find yourself looking for ways to speed up your workflow. Hey, no problem. There are tons of plugins that people have created and shared. Craft is a suite of plugins created by inVision.

  1. Download Craft (https://www.invisionapp.com/craft)
  2. Open CraftInstaller
  3. Click the [C] in your menu bar and select Sketch

Now when you open Sketch, you’ll see a Craft option in your menu bar.

Step 3: Download the DDK

To harness version control and release notes, the library lives on Github.

  1. Go to the GH repo (https://github.com/crdschurch/crds-design)
  2. Click the green button (Clone or download) and select Download Zip
  3. Unzip the folder

Step 4: Load the Library into Sketch

Hang tight, there are just a few more hoops to jump through.

  1. In Sketch, start a new document or open an existing one
  2. If the Craft panel is not visible, choose Craft > Toggle Panel
  3. Click the Library icon in the panel
  4. Select Import Library
  5. Open the unzipped folder (the one you downloaded from Github)

Note: As part of the digital branding standards, you’ll need to acquire the following typefaces, all of which are available at Typekit:

  • Acumin Pro (Thin, Light, Semibold)
  • Acumin Pro SemiCondensed (Semibold)
  • Acumin Pro ExtraCondensed (Semibold)
  • Lexia (Italic)

Tips for using the Library

  • The overall organization of the library is more natural language than what you’ll find on the DDK site.
  • Use the search function to quickly find what you need.
  • Some symbols are designed to accommodate a theme, for instance a low-light app used during an event. Prepended to the symbol’s name, you’ll see a white circle  ⚪️  for light theme and a black circle  ⚫️  for dark theme.
  • If you’re starting a new document, begin by dragging one of the device’s sizes from the Artboard section. These artboards contain the layout grids defined in the Responsive Web Design section of the DDK.
  • Some symbols, like buttons or alerts, utilize Overrides (a subset of the Inspector panel). Whenever a symbol has the same design but a slightly different treatment, overrides are typically employed. Think of an input field within a form. It was a default state but also one for focus, disabled and validation. When these options exist, look for a blue diamond

contentblocks.title: DesignersGetStartedResponsive
contentblocks.content:
Responsive Web Design

Responsive Web Design (RWD) is the methodology of writing mark-up once, then using CSS and media queries to best present the content to whatever device being used. You may think RWD and Mobile First are frenemies but they’re more like that quirky couple whose ever changing passion for one another is secretly envied by everyone else. You know who I’m talking about. Instead of designing and coding different layouts for mobile, tablets and laptops, we use front-end code to manipulate the page elements to shine at any size.

In our layouts, we’ll use the same 12 column grid, resized for each breakpoint. This example compares the smallest grid, mobile, with the largest one, desktop.

Cool theory? Check it out in practice

Say you have a sweet mobile layout ready to go. There’s a photo that spans 12 columns with copy below and a button CTA. When this layout is scaled up to desktop, it’s huge. I mean HUGE. Enter RWD. We can now take the same 3 elements, make the photo span 6 columns and float the copy and button to the right in the remaining 6 columns. In a snippet of code, the layout is reworked for desktop.

Content within fixed containers will reside between the left edge of the 1 column and the right of the 12 column. The outer margin on each side is equally divided, centering the layout in the browser. The majority of our page content, particularly long text pages, reside in fixed containers. The other option is to use fluid containers which will proportionally distribute the same grid across the entire width of the browser. An example of this is a large impact billboard or a maybe a navigation bar that spans the width of the page. Even when using these fluid containers, you can still nest a fixed container to keep the content in your predefined column widths.

If you’re designing around a specific device size, these grid breakpoints may be handy. But basically it’s one grid (to rule them all).

DeviceWidthColumnsGuttersOuter margins
Mobile 353px 12 @ 1px 11 @ 26px 15px
Mobile HD 576px 12 @ 18px 11 @ 30px 15px min.
Tablet Portrait 768px 12 @ 34px 11 @ 30px 15px min.
Desktop 996px 12 @ 53px 11 @ 30px 15px min.
Desktop HD 1200px 12 @ 70px 11 @ 30px 15px min.

contentblocks.title: DevelopersGetStarted
contentblocks.content:
What is the DDK?

The Digital Design Kit, aka DDK, is a website that provides guidance and usage details for implementing various patterns and styles, geared to towards the organization’s designers & developers.

You can think of the DDK as a glorified reference document. Whenever you’re looking for the official rules around a UI element or need to know the proper approach for placing icons in pages or are curious if a UX pattern to resolve some issue has already been adopted by the organization, the DDK is the place to look first.

What is crds-styles?

The shared, global style package that powers Crossroads’ digital properties, a.k.a. crds-styles, is a separate NPM package that should be installed in your application as a dependency.

Overtime, the DDK will grow and mature, as will the shared package that powers it. Be sure to review the semantic versioning rules and project roadmap to protect yourself from accidental regressions as the package changes over time.

contentblocks.title: DevelopersGetStartedInstall
contentblocks.content:
Installation

The following guidelines assume you have a functioning application with support for consuming NPM dependencies and compiling SCSS files at runtime.

Installing crds-styles is a two step process.

The first step involves installing crds-styles and updating your application to consume the styles provided by it. The second step requires an update to your build process so that the physical assets (SVGs) included in crds-styles get copied into your dist/ directory during a build.

Install the Styles

Execute the following command to update your application dependencies...

This will update the devDependencies section of your package.json file with an entry for the crds-styles package and install the new require in your local node_modules directory.

crds-styles already includes the entire Bootstrap CSS library in it’s manifest, so there’s no need to add that package as a separate dependency.

Next, import crds-styles by adding the following line within your application’s SCSS manifest file...

Update Your Build Process

To render the icons provided by crds-styles, the precompiled SVGs must be publicly accessible to your users.

In order to make them available across environments, we recommend copying those assets from the node_modules/crds-styles/assets directory during the build process so they can be served right alongside your application’s other bundled assets.

An example configuration for Webpack builds might look like this…

Crossroads has standardized on Webpack v1 at the time of this writing. If you’re using another task-runner (Angular-CLI, Gulp, etc.) to compile your application, the process may look a little different.

Restart your application and you’re done. You can now take advantage of all the styles, selectors and various patterns illustrated throughout the DDK and/or official Bootstrap documentation.

contentblocks.title: DevelopersGetStartedStyle
contentblocks.content:
Coding Style

In keeping with Bootstrap conventions, Crossroads has adopted the patterns of Object-Oriented CSS (OOCSS) when developing the crds-styles package. Developed in 2008 by Nicole Sullivan, the OOCSS methodology is a modular approach to organizing your CSS by promoting composability and flexibility.

Consider the following example...

This is pretty verbose. We can make these selectors a little cleaner by refactoring them in an object-oriented fashion...

The general gist of OOCSS is that common declarations are encapsulated into base selectors and then augmented by more specific ones. Given the above refactored approach, you might find an element in your HTML that looks like this...

contentblocks.title: DevelopersGetStartedStructure
contentblocks.content:
File Structure

Since crds-styles is meant to be imported directly into your scss-compatible project, there is no actual build process included to generate compiled CSS output. The build script included in the project simply exists to facilitate the continuous integration environment by which we publish new versions of the package to NPM.

Stylesheets

All stylesheets are contained within the assets/stylesheets directory. This convention follows suit with bootstrap-sass and allows for a sensible, framework-agnostic file-path that may be extended to other package management solutions down the road.

In keeping with the modular methodology of OOCSS, we’ve organized the file-structure for all .scss files in crds-styles with a similarly, modular approach. All files are organized within one of the following groups…

Base

Global element rules, included first, that may be inherited by more specific components. Examples include: html, body element defaults, global pseudo classes, reset rules, etc.

Components

Distinct UI components that are styled independent of their context. Examples include: buttons, headings, alerts, form elements, etc.

Layouts

Global components that comprise the overall page layout of any given template. Examples include: container elements, global header, global footer etc.

Themes

Augmentations of certain global rules related to distinct “themes”, such as the ‘dark-theme’ visible within the DDK.

Utilities

Composable helper classes and selectors that aren’t tied to a specific components or layouts belong in the utilities group. Examples include: text-center, bg-success, etc.

For each group above, there is an included _modules.scss file which acts as a manifest for the entire directory. When adding new files to any of these directories, you’ll want to update the manifest to import your new addition.

SVGs

All included icons are formatted as individual SVG files and saved to the src/assets/svgs directory. When recompiling the SVG sprite, the build command will automatically include any file contained within this directory and generate a new version of the sprite located in assets/svgs.

When creating new icons, please refer to the documentation to ensure consistent display and flexibility across browsers & platforms.

contentblocks.title: DevelopersGetStartedNaming
contentblocks.content:
Naming Conventions

Names for any .sass and/or .scss files should be prepended with an underscore character (e.g. _variables.scss). This convention tells the Sass compiler to not generate an individual copy of this file within the build directory.

When naming SVGs for inclusion in the compiled sprite, please follow the general conventions imposed by Font-Awesome. Each name should consist of a descriptor and optional modifier that provides a distinction related to direction or shape with a hyphen delimiting the two values.

For example, a chevron icon that points right should be called chevron-right.svg while a search icon should be named search.svg or search-circle.svg (to denote an icon encapsulated with a circle).

contentblocks.title: DevelopersGetStartedContribute
contentblocks.content:
Contribution Tips

Contributions to crds-styles and/or crds-styleguide (the DDK) are encouraged and may be facilitated through Github's pull-request feature.

If you don't have publishing rights to the repository you'd like to contribute to, simply fork the repository to your own account and submit a pull-request that describes the nature of your changes and what features and/or defects it addresses.

Or you can just send an email to design@crossroads.net.

contentblocks.title: DevelopersLearnCustomNPM
contentblocks.content:
Shared Code

When developing applications for Crossroads, copying and pasting code from one location to another is generally discouraged. For this reason, we've developed several custom packages that empower developers to integrate common portions of business logic into their node-compatible application.

Below is a (non-exhaustive) list of the more commonly referenced packages...

crds-styles

Includes a set of customized stylesheets that enable developers to quickly add stylistic defaults to thier application.
https://github.com/crdschurch/crds-styles

crds-ng2-content-block

This package will enable you to easily integrate content-blocks into your NG2 application.
https://github.com/crdschurch/crdschurch/crds-ng2-content-block

crds-shared-header

The shared header is a framework agnostic implementation of the responsive, global navigation menu.
https://github.com/crdschurch/crds-shared-header

crds-reactive-auth

This little library adds callbacks to your app that can be invoked when a user authenticates themselves.
https://github.com/crdschurch/crds-reactive-auth

contentblocks.title: DevelopersLearnFonts
contentblocks.content:
Web Fonts

To ensure consistent treatment of typography, whether digital or print – Crossroads has curated a specific set of typefaces that should be used when rendering any marketing materials or related content.

For digital media, we rely heavily on the inclusion of Adobe Typekit to aid in the delivery and optimal performance for stylized web-fonts. Integration is as simple as dropping the following snippet into the <head> element on your page.

When working on or deploying applications that are new to the organization, you may need to work with your product owner to include the domain for your project within the "allowed domains" whitelist in Typekit.

contentblocks.title: DevelopersLearnImgix
contentblocks.content:
Imgix

We use Imgix to serve our images. This assures the correct image size is delivered to the browser based on the size of the container and viewport of the device used to view the page. It also functions as a powerful CDN for any user-generated content which means faster delivery and better caching.

Its easy to use too. Simply prefix any image uploaded to the CMS with //crds-cms-uploads.imgix.net/ and you can immediately take advantage of the powerful features and benefits provided by Imgix.

There are lots of options for configuring and using this service so please checkout their documentation when integrating this service into your application.

contentblocks.title: DevelopersLearnGrid
contentblocks.content:
Grid

The standard 12-column grid provided by Bootstrap is alive & well and empowers us to easily create mobile-first layouts with sensible defaults across many different device-sizes. Please refer to the documentation for the finer points of manipulating columns and grid sizes.

Rather than use the clunky, non-semantic grid selectors like .col-xs-*, etc. to manipulate your columns, it is preferable to encapsulate this logic in your scss files using the provided mixins.

DON’T do this…

Do this, instead…

The above, recommended approach decouples the presentational markup from the page structure, which allows for more flexibility across breakpoints and easier long-term maintenance. The entire list of grid-specific mixins provided by crds-styles can be viewed on Github.

contentblocks.title: DevelopersLearnCSS
contentblocks.content:
CSS/SASS

In effort to maintain a consistent codebase, we’ve implemented stylelint in crds-styles to help enforce some general rules to follow when formatting new style declarations. While you can expect these rules to change over time, the basic ruleset can be viewed here.

To manually execute the linter against the crds-styles project, simply execute the following command…

Currently, linter rules are not enforced during the build process but it’s a good idea to observe their feedback regularly and correct any violations as you encounter them. If you’re using VSCode, you can install the vscode-stylelint plugin for real-time feedback.

contentblocks.title: DevelopersLearnBootstrap
contentblocks.content:
Powered By Bootstrap

Bootstrap is the most popular, open-source front-end framework for developing responsive, mobile-first projects on the web.

Used across the internet to power some of the world’s most compelling websites, Bootstrap provides the stable, battle-tested foundation on which crds-styles is built. Because it inherits directly from Bootstrap, all of the conventions and components provided by that framework are available when adding crds-styles to your project.

Learn more at http://getbootstrap.com/

Bootstrap Components for NG1.5 & NG2

Out of the box, Bootstrap provides a handful of jQuery plugins which provide some interactivity for many of the components built into the framework. Since jQuery isn’t often available within Angular applications (why?) we rely on 3rd-party packages to provide the same or similar functionality within our applications.

For projects running versions of Angular greater than v2, we recommend NGX-Bootstrap. For earlier versions of Angular, checkout Angular-UI.

While you may see an example of a component rendered within the DDK, it is generally best to refer to the official documentation for that component as things can change dramatically from version to version.

contentblocks.title: DevelopersIntro
contentblocks.content:
Developers, Start Your IDEs

Proper implementation of brand-standards is hard enough — even in traditional media. In a digital context, adhering to well-intentioned guidelines is not only tricky but can be difficult to maintain over the lifetime of any project. DDK to the rescue!

This website was specifically developed to empower developers with all the implementation details they need to be successful while working on digital properties for Crossroads. This approach allows the brand to maintain cohesion & consistency through the use of well-established patterns by helping deliver quality user-experience with minimal effort.

Getting Started Learn More


One Package to Rule Them All

By building your work on-top of the patterns described within the DDK, you’ll be leaning on approved, established styles.

No more guess-work around implementation; no more wondering if your CSS will get rejected during acceptance review; simply copy the provided example code, override where needed and move on with your day.

See the NPM Package

Built On Bootstrap

We’ve taken the Bootstrap CSS Framework you know and love and extended it to support approved patterns that are in use all across Crossroads’ digital properties. Through the use of NPM and other related technologies, simply include one package and you’re off to the races.

Learn Bootstrap

Open Source

Like all digital projects for Crossroads, the full-source of both the DDK and it supporting libraries are open-source and ready for your contributions. From PRs to individual release-notes, keep track of what exists today, where we've been and where we're heading.

Got something you need, something we missed or discovered a regression? Let us know!

Fork Us on Github
